title: Anet A8 Front Sensor Holder with Integrated Fan Guard for Removable Fan

description.text:
Okay, I have this pretty handy sensor mount thing designed by Leo_N, and it seemed like every time I'd go to touch the carriage, my finger would hit the fan. Not that it hurt, but it'd surprise me and make me jump! What to do? Get (make) a grill for the fan! Looking around, I find valadium's Fan Removable Assembly, and I kinda liked the looks of the grill. Just kind of neat looking. Well, I liked the sensor mount, and I liked the grill... and I'm not that good at Sketchup, so i decided to learn a little and combine them. So, this is what I came up with. Seems to work pretty well!

I hope people can get some use out of this collaboration. Enjoy!

description.text:
This is two parts that snap together to make a holder for a 7/8" marble, with a hole to hang it. I included VRML files with vertex coloring, and STL files for monochrome printers. There's a smaller one for a 5/8" marble here.

Marbles aren't made precisely, so measure yours with calipers. It'll be fine if it's a bit small, but if it's oversize the parts will either not snap together (SLS) or break (sandstone/ZCorp/CJP material).

Also if it's in a more brittle material, don't drop it. I stand before you, sadder but wiser.

Printer:

3D Systems Project CJP series

Supports:

No

Notes:

I'm sorry, I get parts from Shapeways and I can't tell you much about how to print these. Here's the link if you'd like to get them there:
http://tinyurl.com/y8oyupu9
http://tinyurl.com/y9cnbonp

You probably need a machine that doesn't use any kind of supports. The material must have a little flexibility for the snap-fit to work. It should be pretty strong and not brittle.

The color (.wrl) version needs, obviously, a color printer.

The hanging hole is 1.4mm diameter, so unless you don't want to hang the thing or are ready to drill it out in post, you'll need that much resolution.

If you have a color print of this from a 3D Systems "sandstone" printer, the part won't flex much. So the marble needs to drop in with only a little snap: if it doesn't, find a smaller one. Also be careful snapping the two halves together, and don't plan to take them apart.

OTOH if you have an SLS nylon print, go to town.

I hung mine by threading a piece of nylon monofil through the hole, then melting the inner end to make a round bead to hold it. A knot in some thread works just as well.
I did the modeling in Rhino and the texture in Meshlab.

I like the Makerbot clips made by berserkerscientist but i wanted the windows to be fitted. I added support to make the window sit the same height as the bottom of the opening. I also made a top window clip so that the window wouldn't flap around when the printer get moving a little.

Print 2 of the Things to get 2 tops and 2 bottoms. The M will show you which 1 is the top and the bottom.  
Place a sheet of paper over each opening and trace the window shape. I taped the paper over the outside and then traced from the inside with a fine point sharpie. Then trace the size on to the 1.5mm acrylic sheet. I used an Exacto knife to cut the shape out.  
Fit the window into the 4 clips. The tension of the sheet will hold the top clips in place.

title: SkyWatcher Star Adventurer to QHY Pole Master adapter

description.text:
Adapter to mount the QHY Pole Master electronic polar scope to the dovetail bar of the SkyWatcher Star Adventurer.
The Adapter fits snug to the long hole in the dovetail bar, so that you may use both bolts for camera, telescope or gear. If the Pole Master camera is not attached, the Star Adventurers built in polar scope has enough clearance to be used.
If printed right, the adapter press-fits into the dovetail, so you event don't have to use screws to hold the adapter in place. (Tested from -14°C to +35°C)
There are 4 screw holes prepared (need M3 tapping), to lock the adapter to the dovetail bar. Just test your individual setup, how many screws you need!
The hole on the ring is prepared for M4 tapping to use a knurled screw with approximately 20-30mm length.

Print with ring part down with supports.

Parts required to finish:
M3 tap
M4 tap
M3 set screws
M4 screw with 20-30mm, best use a knurled head screw

description.text:
Redesigned Extruder bracket, x_carriage, and x-axis for Orballo i3 style printer.

"Stock" redesign solves the following problems

  1. The hot-end touching & melting the x_carriage.
  2. Improved cooling. At a minimum you'll need the following Fan Duct: http://e3d-online.com/E3D-v6/Spares/v6-Injection-Moulded-Fan-Duct?limit=100 (just a couple of $ for 2). This, however, did NOT solve my heat creep problem with PLA. ABS prints VERY reliably though.
  3. Beefier inductive sensor bracket that's farther away from bed to allow easier adjustment.

"Upgrade" redesign additionally solves the following problems:

  1. Threaded rods stripped the nuts in original design - replaced with 8mm lead screws and nuts (both found on eBay).
  2. Original Hot end had a heat creep problem that prevented reliable PLA prints - replaced with branded E3Dv6 kit (http://e3d-online.com/E3D-v6/Full-Kit/v6-1.75mm-Universal)

You do not need to print all parts - with Stock Orballo print "Main Body_remodeled_stock hot end.stl". If you decided to upgrade to E3Dv6, print other one. "X_Idler" and "X-Motor" files are not required if not upgrading to 8mm Lead screws.

Printer:

Orballo i3 (Prusa Style)

No

Doesn't Matter

0.2mm

at least 50%

Print in ABS at least 50% infill (debatable if more is better).

Shell Thickness 0.8 (4 layers) - no layer cooling.

With PEI bed (standard on Orballo) - just clean with rubbing alcohol before each print (no glue or other adhesion required)

einfache Tischbeinverlängerung (Lack Tisch)

this is a nice and simple model for a 3 legged fidget spinner for 625 sized bearings which are commonly used on 3d printers.
to make this spinner, you will need to print:
1X fidget spinner.stl
2X spinnerCap.stl
you will also need 4X 625 size bearings.
the cap should be printed upside down (top down);

assembly:
the bearings and caps need to be hammered in to place, without damaging the bearings.
1.after printing, put the spinner on a flat surface, take one bearing and place it on one of the spinner holes.

  1. take a block of scrap wood- and place on top of the bearing
  2. hit the wood with a hammer until the bearing sits flush inside the spinner.
    repeat the process for all 4 bearings, and 2 spinner caps
  3. enjoy your spinner!

title: Sony Minolta A-Mount to 1.25 inch telescope eyepiece adapter

description.text:
With this adapter you can connect any 1.25 inch eyepiece / camera to a Sony / Minolta A-Mount lens.
The adapter opens up the aperture completely for maximum light. The lens should have a tripod mount, as this adapter has none.
Use a M2.5 screw or similar to lock the adapter to the lens (this would be the bolt from the camera, holding the lens in place)
There is no further support required and even not recommended, as the rather fragile aperture lever part would be hard to clear from the supports. The aperture lever has a small support part attached in the design, which is easy to break away.

Be careful as 1.25 inch cameras may slide all through to the lens and cause damage if not properly locked!

description.text:
This is a 22mm band for the Samsung Gear S3 smartwatch, (but it could work with other 22mm watches). I designed this because I was tired of searching for a band that suit my needs and look sturdy and cool. There are a lot of cheap bands out there, but I am a maker, you know what I mean... Designed sturdy in accordance to the watch looks. No vitamins required. Snap type fit (I call it macro-velcro) & secure closing. Recommended to change filament color at 2 or 3mm height for a cool bicolor look. Part3 requires baseplate support. I am using Ninjaflex due to its strength but any TPE material will work. Keep in mind that this looks better on big wrists...

Also provided an adapter to other 22mm bands just in case. Print the adapter in PLA or ABS (not flex).

Enjoy!

(11-JUL-2017):
Production started. Minor enhancemets. Angled 20º the watch fit. Raised the pin hole by 1mm to sunken the watch's fit. Added a longer band for bigger wrists (should be enough). Updated design and STL's accordingly. Will post pics of new hi-res builds when prints complete. Working slowly as I have only one machine on flex at this time and have little spare time due to work...

(10-JUL-2017):
Pics of my quick B&W lo-res build added (0.2mm layer, NinjaFlex). There's still place for enhancements, keep tuned...

(09-JUL-2017)
Main tests ended. Removed the work in progress status. Working models posted. Updated stl's and sources. Enhanced grip to watch, rebuild buckle's STL which had a tricky render problem (couldn't find the point, but it works now). Rounded strap ends. Minor tests still in progress. Pics will soon be posted when I print a decent build, but at this time I can say it is working better than expected... Maybe I post a longer strap for you guys with larger wrists. Ask for it if needed. Adapter 22mm STL added (ABS/PLA)

(07-JUL-2017):
Project started. Posted a work-in-progress prototype. Tests pending. Requesting feedback. No feedback received, continuing research on my own...

remixed_from.title: Really High accuracy adjustable Z Endstop for Prusa

description.text:
Based on the excellent designs by
jedynak, here is a parametric version of an adjustable Z endstop holder(I use 6 mm rods etc). Hope it can help ! edit : added some pics of it (temporarily) mounted on the z axis for clarity. edit2 : slightly changed the endstop holder, for more stability, works well now

Works, but needs a few more tweaks and refinements.
Print, add bolts, nuts and an adapted spring. Optional:
  • the "hammer" part can be used (for example for wallace type x ends) with mechanical endstops : mount the hammer on the x-end vertically and the end of the hammer should press down on the endstop switch
  • lower helper: if the endstop holder arm is too wobbly to your taste, just print this part and mount it right underneath the rest of the endstop holder, it will hold the spring mounted bolt in place.

title: FLSUN Kossel Mini: Double radial fan mount

description.text:
I recently bought the 'new' FLSUN Kossel mini. I came to the conclusion that the included radial fan is a bit weak, and therefore decided to design a mount capable up to two 12V 50 mm radial fans.

Unfortunately, the 'new' FLSUN Kossel mini design leaves little to no room for fans under the end-effector. Thus, this fan mount replaces the designated space occupied by the original radial fan. The mount is fixed firmly (press-fitting) and is fixed securely.

Both PLA and ABS are suitable for this fan mount, since the heat from the hot-end isn't significant to warp the PLA. To be safe, I wrapped the mount in Kapton tape.

DISCLAIMER
Watch out with the fan-speed! going from 0-100% after the first layer typically results in a thermal runaway. My suggestion is going 35% for the first layer and then 70% fanspeed in the cura settings under cooling.

author: wdryja

description.text:
The shower stall in my house has textured tiles, and the suction cups to stabilize a shower caddy that hangs on the shower head will not stick to them. So I made this bracket that allows the caddy to be hung on the glass panes of the stall. It's a very simple design, but thought somebody might find it useful.

There are two parts, which attached together onto the hanger of the caddy. I used a 6-32 brass insert and a screw to attach them together, but it would be easy to modify to just use a screw and a nut.

Also, the design is probably somewhat oversized. You could probably shrink it and use less material when printing.

En esta página está la información sobre el diseño, construcción y montaje de la electrónica que controla a mi robot DYOR.

  • En la siguiente dirección se ve el diseño realizado con tinkercad.
    https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kPqYyWr1nnf

  • En la siguiente dirección se puede ver un pequeño vídeo con el montaje y decoración de las piezas: https://youtu.be/13eyn0ICpj0

  • También aparece un listado de los materiales electrónicos necesarios y una imagen con su posible construcción realizada con Fritzing.

  • En la siguiente dirección se puede ver un pequeño vídeo que muestra el montaje de la electrónica sobre la base del motor así como el conexionado de los diferentes elementos a la placa de control Arduino: https://youtu.be/ioRe9CD49Jw

Los componentes electrónicos y accesorios necesarios para llevar a la práctica el diseño que se muestra son los siguientes:
  • 1 Arduino nano v3.0 y placa de expansión I/O Arduino nano
  • 1 batería USB (powerbank)
  • 2 micro servos de rotación continua FS90R y ruedas de 60mm
  • 2 micro servos SG90
  • 1 sensor de ultrasonidos SR-HC04
  • 1 módulo seguilíneas TCRT5000
  • 1 matriz de LEDs 8x8 (max7219)
  • 1 zumbador pasivo (KY-006)
  • 1 módulo bluetooth HC-06
  • 1 rueda loca
  • Piezas lego 6x1 brick
  • 1 cable usb
  • 1 móvil o tablet Android

Para más información sobre la construcción del robot consultar: Curso MOOC EdX: https://www.edx.org/course/disena-fabrica-y-programa-tu-propio-upvalenciax-dyor101x
Portal de formación robot DYOR: http://dyor.roboticafacil.es
Blog robótica de la UPV: http://robotica.webs.upv.es
Twitter (@roboticaUPV): https://twitter.com/roboticaUPV
Facebook (robótica UPV): https://www.facebook.com/roboticaUPV

title: Prusa i3 MK2 LED Lighting Mount

description.text:
Stop!

There is a new and improved version -- print that instead :)
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2667553

Update:

I uploaded this before finishing the installation. In hindsight, I might have done things differently with this. The tabs at the top of each arm are there for wire management -- they don't really do much for this purpose. I might have tried to make a path inside the model for this if I had given this more thought. Other wire management is also not awesome, currently, I'm using black tape on the back of the frame for most of it. But I am looking for a better option.

Additionally, the strip lighting is a poor choice for this. I would recommend getting a small LED panel instead. I was able to fit 10 3 light segments on each side (which only draws about 300ma of power by the way, for both sides combined). But soldering all of the connections was a real pain (maybe someone more adept with a soldering iron wouldn't see it as such). Additionally, there isn't a lot of room for the wires so you can kind of see them.

That said I am keeping mine setup this way. It does provide a nice amount of light and I am happy with my installation. But if anyone wants to remix this into something a little more polished that would be great.

I have included the Fusion 360 file for the left arm and the switch holder, the right arm was flipped using Tinkercad.

In any case, I hope this is helpful to some folks.

Parts Needed

LED Strip -- Here is what I used:
https://amazon.com/gp/product/B00HSF65MC/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1&sa-no-redirect=1

Switch -- Here is one like I used:
https://amazon.com/AutoEC-Rocker-Toggle-Switch-Control/dp/B012IJ38S6/ref=sr_1_13?ie=UTF8&qid=1499352050&sr=8-13&keywords=12v+switch+red+led

Notes, etc...

I was using a LED holder, thing 2120195, but I recently added a cable chain to my MK2S and mostly from thing 2224025, and the light bar wasn't working right. So I decided to look for a replacement. I couldn't find anything that quite matched what I wanted, so I designed this.

I designed the left one in Fusion 360 and used Tinkercad to flip it for the right one.

I have noticed the left side does interfere -- very slightly -- with Z calibration. I'm not sure I could redesign it to prevent that -- it seems to just touch the bearing on X carriage. In my case, I am still able to complete the calibration but sometimes it pushes the LED bracket up slightly. I probably won't change anything for this at this point.

I have designed the switch mount to fit loosely above the power supply (i.e it will move up and down) but it may take a bit of pressure (it did with my PETG parts) to get it to mount on the frame. If it is too loose for your liking, being able to move it up or down, you can do as I did, which is to take a small zip tie and cut off about 20 mm or so off the end. You can slip this between the frame and the side of the switch bracket to act as a shim (see image). You could skip the switch -- but for me, the switch was nice because there are times I want to be printing but not have the lights on.

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2MM

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I used PETG -- the mounts might be a bit tight for a less flexible filament -- they are pretty snug on my prints. If you print this you will need to orient the flat side down, should be fairly obvious. I printed them one at a time, not sure if you could do two on one build plate or not. I did angle mine as it barely fits the build plate straight on.

Highly recommend heat resistant material on the parts you will need to solder against.

description.text: Simple cooling bracket/duct for a small fan to cool a larger nema17 stepper motor.

This is a simple duct/bracket that attaches a small cooling fan to the side of a nema17 stepper.  This is a relatively simple object (my first in google sketchup).  
It easily slides over the printrbot x-axis stepper or the extruder stepper -> works quite well.
I didn't find that a heatsink was needed, but it would be easy slightly increase the channel and attach one under inside the duct.
If necessary there are two 3mm holes to increase the strenght of the sttachment to the stepper.
The particular motor I used was a sunon kde1204pkvx (40x40mm).

description.text:
Diamond shaped LED desk lamp.
Approx. size 3 1/2" x 2 3/4" x 2 3/4"
Uses any old 5 volt cell phone charger to produce a quality visual effect.
Some electronics required.

Print all parts with raft, no supports required. I used 1 shell with 50% fill. Takes about 2 hours to complete this project.
Use a 5Volt, 500mA cell phone charger, with a 100ohm 1/4 Watt resistor in series and an ultra-bright LED. Slide the diffuser over led, glue down the wires and then glue the shade to the base.
Much time was spent on the diffuser to get even lighting I'm really happy with the result.
Enjoy!

remixed_from.author: kungfuroy
remixed_from.title: Parts I used for my Modified Printrbot Simple

remixed_from.author: iamjonlawrence
remixed_from.title: Timing Belt Y GT2, Printrbot Simple V2

description.text:
Upgrade your Y axis to 300 mm (12") or more or less, GT2 belt drive, and eliminate Y-Sag in one mod...
  • I upgraded to 300 mm capacity here only because I had a piece of 8 mm rod 915 mm (36") long and didn't want to waste it. Not to mention "just because I can." I am currently only using 150 mm to reach the edge of my 6" heat bed, but have run it all the way out and it is extremely stable over the entire distance. Rod & belt lengths can be adjusted to whatever you dare. Only requirement is that the lower rod is 50 mm (2") longer than the top.
  • Increased linear bearing centers from the stock 24 mm to 64 mm. What this means is 3x the overhang possible, effectively eliminating Y-sag common to the Simple. I was surprised at how solid the Y axis is now.
  • Designed to hold stock wooden direct drive extruder. Not tested with aluminum DDE.
    • Requirements:
  • 95 mm x 95 mm print area
  • The ability to print FLAT without edges lifting
  • Well calibrated printer
  • GT2 20 tooth belt pulley. 18 tooth will not clear bearing
  • Z axis Hex nut to measure 1/2" across flats
  • Y/X axis at 90 degrees.
    • 2014-02-19, REV.B: Added ZScrewMount for printers purchased after 10/23/2013 where they changed the Z screw assembly. Also changed Z Endstop Extension to a better design. 2014-03-17, REV.C: Modified Z nut mounting to accomodate ACME nut. Uploaded new version of ExtendYPlate.stl as ExtendYPlateRevC.stl. 2014-03-23: Uploaded front plate for 2014 Simple fan and aluminum extruder. "ExtendYFront2014AlExtruder.stl" 2014-03-24: Uploaded front plate for 2014 Simple, Fan, Aluminum extruder, and Cable management. "ExtendYFront2014AlExtruderCable.STL" 2014-03-25: Updated "ExtendYFront2014ExtruderCable.stl" to "ExtendYFront2014ExtruderCableRevA.stl" which includes mounting for a bolt on fan duct extension. Also uploaded "ExtendYFanDuct.stl" as the extension piece for the fan duct. 2014-04-02: Uploaded a version of the front end for the 2013 Simple that includes a side mounted fan like the 2014. "ExtendYFront2013Fan.slt" Use with "ExtendYFanDuct.stl" 2014-04-07: Uploaded a version of the rear end that allows the use of identical length rods. With this rear end the rod lengths need to be at least 175mm longer than your desired stroke. 2014-04-14: Uploaded an updated version of the end stop flag RevA. This will allow you to insert the belt thru the flag and remove some of the belt vibration. 2014-04-17: Uploaded an updated version of the front end for the aluminum extruder that includes some extra supports. "ExtendYFront2014AlExtruderRevA.stl" 2014-05-11: Uploaded a version of the rear end that uses a clamp to secure the rods, and allows the upper rod to pass thru, so equal length rods can be used. "ExtendYRearClamp.stl" This design was inspired by kingfuroy's Modified Simple http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:238932 Feedback is strongly encouraged.

• Drill out the 8mm rod holes to clean up. Do not drill thru. I actually used a 5/16" bit (didn't have an 8mm) and just wiggled it a bit to oversize the hole to 8mm-ish. The rods press in nice and tight.
  • Reuse Z stop screw & mounting blocks.
    • Tips:
  • Install extruder end of GT2 belt before mounting extruder. It is really difficult to reach afterwords.
  • To locate the drive pulley, slide the pulley on the shaft but do not tighten the set screws (grub screws). Thread the belt and just hold tension by hand. Slide the axis by hand and the pulley will spin on the shaft and locate itself. Tighten the screws to lock it in.
  • To get belt length correct, thread belt thru machine and thru rear tension block. Mark where the belt exits the rear tension block and cut belt 10-20mm past that point to give enough length to fold over. Slip belt off 608 bearing. This will give you enough length to fold on your mark and insert belt back in tension block.
  • Don't go crazy tightening the bearing block screws. Just snug them up. The part geometry will hold the bearings with very little screw force.
  • Use "M208 Y300" or "M211 Y300" to increase preset limits. If neither of these work you may need to flash your firmware with the "Marlin Unified V2" firmware then use "M211 Y300". Follow the guide published by Printrbot at: http://help.printrbot.com/Guide/How+to+Reflash+Firmware/78

comments.text: I think I'm going to remend modifying the front mount again. The rods sit too far back on one end of the front piece allowing the weight of everything but the fan to pull down (including any additionally mounted fan or probe). I decided to used 400mm rods. I'm trying to get 300mm usable print area. So the end effect is that as the y axis goes out all the way, the weight of everything in front of the rods (mostly the motor) twists the entire end enough to make printing that far out unusable. If the rods could be moved more toward the middle of the front mount, the twisting would not occur. It would mean giving up some mm in the X axis to gain the full 300 on Y, but in my case that's not an issue since I also have 300mm usable on X. Help!
comments.author: willrawls

comments.text: Well I managed to correct for the twist by adding a ballast bar. I used one of my extra shorter 8mm rods and suspended it at 90 degrees to the other two bars mounting it on the front piece with most of the bar acting as a counter weight. Of course that's not enough weight, so I took a small death star I had previously printed and drilled 3 holes in it, Two to let the 8mm bar through and one in the top to let me fill the hollow moon with rice. This was just enough weight to counterweight the twist... I now appear to have 300x300x165 printing... Hopefully this will hold.

comments.text:
So, I built this and it has dramatically improved my prints. I've gone from reliably printing at 30mm/s to 60mm/s after installing this mod. Not to mention the extra build area.
However, it is SUPER LOUD. Like, WAY louder than my Simple was before the mod. Has anyone been able to mitigate this issue?
comments.author: jnovek

comments.text:
These printers definitely have a natural resonance where the frequency of the motors matches the frame and they amplify each other. This has nothing to do with the belt drive. For me it is around 60mm/s where the motors are the loudest.
Try lowering your acceleration & jerk settings and increasing your speed to around 80mm/s. They should quiet down around that speed. You can also play with the Speed Multiply "Feedrate" in Repetier during a print to find where it runs the quietest.
comments.author: jnovek

comments.text:
Resonance seemed to be it. I got rubber cupboard liner under it and that dampened the noise substantially.
Also, at 80mm/s (my max reliable speed so far) the printer was walking around quite a bit. The cupboard liner fixed that as well!

comments.text: I Use this but for the front end i use the new extruder mount that was made for the Alummunim extruder only insted my extruder its all plastic the the j- head is set so not to transfer heat up to the plastic extruder. A lot of the sag in the {Y} comes from the way the rods in the {Z} are mounted in the wood.And the more you extend the {Y} the more the Sage will be because the {Z} rods need to be spread apart to compensate for the extended {Y} and that will mean changing the {Z} base. The printrbot Simple is a great design for starters but as you upgrade you will run into problems with designs you need to change. But when useing the {Y} carrage do not over Tighten where the bearings go because its not a 100% fit and 1 degree can cause a bunce of problems. After hours of fine tunning and changing my print bed to 1 inch plywood counter bored for the screws and mounted solid with no adjustmen only in the {Z} direction. Have 2 heat beds tied in series run to the print-board running on a 300w ATX power supply. I can hold tolerance 10mm cube at { Z:10 Y:10.5 X:10.5} . To keep my prints starting nice i keep the heat bed set at 48c for PLA and use Elmer's Glue sticks. I only need to apply the glue to the table once every 5 prints. working on getting speed in printing while keeping the tolerance in check.

comments.text: Thanks for the heads up on the bearing blocks.  As for the X axis, I plan to make some aluminum mounts for the bearings and mount them to the 80/20 track and space the extrusions along two outer rails and lock them down with the bed, rails, and bearings already mounted to the track, this should help eliminate binding as everything will be locked down already aligned.  Still undecided what to use for the bed frame, but it will probably be some aluminum end caps for the 8mm rails and an aluminum plate that I will freeze with dry ice to stabilize and then machine it flat with a few holes so that can be held down with screws to the end caps and shimmed to level.  With the improved rigidity I'm expecting less variation, and less adjusting the bed level.  the Z axis rods will get their own end caps that will mount to the 80/20 track at the top and bottom so they can be locked down after I square them to the world(printer base).  Simply shimming the mounts for the Z rods will allow squaring the Y axis to the X axis.

comments.text: The rods inserted into the end mounts stabilize the structure. The lower rod on this needs to be 175mm longer than your  desired print volume. comments.author: danman1178

comments.text: You can always use 5/16" rod from your local hardware store.  The 5/16" rod is 0.0025" smaller than 8mm, and I can guarantee you that any printed plastic part 95mm x 95mm will vary much more than that.  If you get one that is not plated and straight (roll it on the table to make sure it doesn't wobble), use some fine grit sandpaper or scotch brite pad to clean it up and you should be good to go.  If you are only looking for 100mm travel, the loads on the bearings are very low with this configuration, so a polished, hardened, chrome plated linear shaft is not required.

A direct drive extruder designed for use with a Minebea geared stepper motor, a Makerbot drive wheel, and a MakerGear GrooveMount (or similar) hot end. Version 3 simplifies the design a bit, and tweaks it to make a stronger print. I left ulti_rcx_2.stl, along with the old sources here because I broke ultimaker support while redesigning it. Version 2 addresses two issues I had with version 1. 1) Idler pressure was very touchy - as you increased pressure on the idler, it would put axial force on the motor's gearbox, which can't be good. I added a pocket for a 115ZZ bearing, to buttress the drive shaft. 2) I found that even with the bearing on the drive shaft, I have to run the motor hotter than I'd like, so I added a bracket for a 40mm fan. Also, I split the extruder body into 2 slices, to make it easier to print. Finally, thanks to canadaduane, we now have a variant which replaces the ultimaker's bowden extruder with a lightweight carriage mounted extruder. P.S. ezmobius (actually, Triffid_Hunter) has designed a fan shroud to go with his extruder body which is better than the bracket I provided, so use the fan shroud from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24390

Vitamins: Extruder bodies (per extruder)
Â Â Â Â 1 Geared stepper motor (Minbea PG35L-D48).
Â Â Â Â 1 Drive wheel (MakerBot MK7, Arcol 11x5, or contact blddk in IRC).
Â Â Â Â 1 115ZZ bearing (5x11x4) (Drive bearing).
Â Â Â Â 1 624ZZ bearing (4x13x5) (Idler bearing).
Â Â Â Â 2 M3 x 25mm Socket head screws (Motor mounting screws).
Â Â Â Â 4 M3 x 35mm Socket head screws (Idler mounting screws).
Â Â Â Â 2 M3 x 20mm Socket head screws (Carriage mounting screws).
Â Â Â Â 1 M4 x 16mm Socket head screws (Idler bearing hub).
Â Â Â Â 8 M3 washers.
Â Â Â Â 8 M3 nyloc nuts (At the very least, use nyloc nuts on the idler).
Â Â Â Â 1 M4 nyloc nut (Idler bearing hub). Motor sources:
Â Â Â Â  eminebea.com/en/product/rotary/steppingmotor/pm/gearbox/pg35l-d48.shtml
Â Â Â Â  mpja.com/prodinfo.asp?number=18840+MS (Mostly Identical to the motor which was previously available at All Electronics, including the vestigial gear. Drive shaft is shorter, so you won't be able to fit a bearing on the end of it.)
Â Â Â Â  http://www.pollin.de/shop/dt/MzE1OTg2OTk-/Motoren/Schrittmotoren/Getriebe_Schrittmotor_NMB_MAT_PG35L_048_USC0.html (European supplier, appears to match the mpja.com motor.) Drive wheel sources:
Â Â Â Â  store.makerbot.com/mk7-drive-gear.html
Â Â Â Â  indiegogo.com/mini-hyena (the 11x5 version).
Â Â Â Â  contact blddk in #reprap irc. If you purchase the motor from mpja.com, you'll need a small gear puller or faucet puller to remove the vestigial gear. Assembly instructions:
Â Â Â Â Use your imagination, lacking that, refer to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22980 . Don't forget to install the drive bearing. Firmware configuration
Â Â Â Â E-Steps/mm (These values will get you close; Calibrate further, or live with crap prints!):
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â makerbot Mk7 with 16x microstepping - 825.698
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â blddk hob with 16x microstepping - 761.328 Â Â Â Â I found that marlin's default settings for E feedrate, acceleration and jerk were all too high for these motors. Â Â Â Â #define DEFAULT_MAX_FEEDRATEÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  {400, 400, 220/60, 45}
Â Â Â Â #define DEFAULT_MAX_ACCELERATIONÂ Â Â {9000,9000,100,500}
Â Â Â Â #define DEFAULT_EJERKÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 1.0 Software configuration
Â Â Â Â Reduce your retract speed to 10mm/sec.

comments.text: Unfortunately, because these were surplus motors, they've become very difficult (if not impossible) to find.  There were two variations that I came across, one with a 12mm drive shaft (which is the one this is designed for), and another with an 8mm drive shaft (which unfortunately, doesn't leave enough room for the drive bearing, which in my experience was required.
comments.author: rocketbob

comments.text: It appears that the Trinity Labs motor/gearbox has enough length on the shaft for a support bearing alongside the hobbed pulley.  It also appears to be shorter than the motor you are using, which would help with X-axis travel.  If I can get a non-stl file format from you (Solidworks part files would be great) I can redesign the extruder for the Trinity Labs motor.
comments.author: raldrich

comments.text: It appears that the trinity labs motors would be a good choice, if the hobbed pulley is short enough to allow enough room for a bearing to fit on the shaft.  I completely agree it needs to be supported.  If I can get non-stl cad files (I use SolidWorks) I can redesign it to work with the Trinity labs motors.  They appear to be a bit shorter than the motors you have used, which would help in getting full x-axis travel.
comments.author: raldrich

comments.text: The metal gearbox motors that they sell don't require a shaft support bearing, because it's not a planetary gearbox.  The gears, however, are sintered brass, and don't hold up over time unless you give them some extra lubricant (This is why trinity decided not to use that motor long term).
comments.author: rocketbob

comments.text: I would stay away from a faucet puller on this one to get the gear off the PG35L. I barely got it off, spent half an hour doing it and ruined the faucet puller in the process because the threads were never designed for that much force.
comments.author: bsull

comments.text: are you running the motor in a bipolar mode with the pololu?
comments.author: ekaggrat

comments.text: I'm really impressed with the print quality you get with these.  I have a few of these from All Electronics from a while ago and I had been planning to build an extruder with them, but I just stumbled upon your design.  It looks great.  I had done an initial design, but didn't really go forward with it because of the motor specs.  The DC resistance is quite high (70 ohms according to data sheet), which is why all the heat.  I tried driving the motor when I first got them but the heat and the fact that the speed is limited deterred me from further work...  This type of motor is usually driven with a less intelligent driver, one that doesn't actively control the current (hence the high internal resistance.)  The internal resistance is meant to protect the motor when a constant voltage is applied.  This really isn't the type of motor that the Allegro chips are meant to drive (compare to the Nema 17 motors which are usually used which have only a few ohms of DC resistance).
comments.author: granz

comments.text: As long as you use a fan or heat sink with them, they seem to be quite reliable.  I've run 16 hour prints with them, without any difficulty, and without them failing the "thumb" test (i.e. I can hold my thumb to the motor without undue pain).

author: wyldin

description.text:
This is supposed to be the most advanced 6 piece puzzle, original designed by Bill Cutler:
http://billcutlerpuzzles.com/stock/baffling.html

You need to do 5 moves to remove the first piece.

Designed with FreeCAD 0.17 (unreleased), you can also find the original FreeCAD file for further modifications.

Some simple OpenSCAD to get the points for lines that are tangential to two arbitrary circles.

I found myself bodging this a lot so used Prof. Google to get some equations to do it properly.

Enjoy!

Update: I've been pointed to this thread where there's a very nice bit of code at the bottom that solves the problem in a different way and is probably easier to use! http://forum.openscad.org/Script-to-replicate-hull-and-minkoswki-for-CSG-export-import-into-FreeCAD-tp16537p16556.html

comments.text: Hull(){} will do pretty much the same, which would also allow you to difference out the cylinders if you wanted to.
comments.author: Wibbly

comments.text: Maybe, but I have at times wanted one central circle and four (or whatever) going out from this, Where OpenSCAD's CSG can do the job, I use it, but increasingly I place the geometry more accurately myself.

title: Dewhooshroom
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mushroom like device for letting air out of inflatable SUP boards without the associated WHOOSH!

Helen from Yoga Bright mentioned that letting the air out has a tendency to blow her hat off. While rather amusing, hat fetching is only fun the first few times...

So, behold, the Dewhooshroom - the thing that takes the whoosh out and looks like a mushroom.

To use, simply prod it into the valve on the SUP and the air will come out quite slowly. To speed things up, tilt it slightly. You'll notice it's nice and quiet but does take about 30 seconds to 1 minute to empty the SUP rather than the 2 seconds of the original WHOOSH.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Support shouldn't be required and lower resolution prints should work fine. It's not as if it has to be air tight...

What can't be seen on the image are an array of 12 holes all about 1mm in diameter. These are what restricts the air flow. If they don't print all that well, it won't matter as long as they are still holes.

Post-Printing

Bury on a tropical island for 1 year
Return to secret location and retrieve
Wash with mineral water while chanting in lydian

title: ANET A8 Z-Axis threaded rod extension for use with self centering coupler

description.text:
Hello,

I simply designed this z-axis extension vor my Anet A8 printer because the Z-Axis threaded rod was a bit to short after i installed this self centering coupler.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:602481

If the straight rod sits too lose on your printer check out this:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2423046

For easy assembly i made the:
Top diameter = 7,8 mm
Diameter for rod = 8,2 mm
Print with 100% infill.

If it is a bit too lose because your printer has a high accuracy try out some teflon tape or cut a stripe of paper and put it between.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8dgVjpkzfnB

comments.text:
You are right and i have not thought about that.
I had no problems with that to today, lets find out why.
I have got out my old book from school.
The rod has a lenght of 350 mm.
And the temperature is going up from 20°C to 50°C .
And Ferrum fe has a Temperaturausdehnungskoeffizient of 0,000012 % per degree.
350 mm x 0,00012 x 30°C = 0,126 mm
I don't think the constuction of the A8 ist that stiff that it can't handle that 0,126 mm.
Disregarded the fact that the acrylic frame does also change the lenght with temperature, not as much as the rod.
comments.author: jetztwirdgedruckt

comments.text:
You are aware that the top of the lead screw is supposed to be free?
If it was fixed at the top, then it would not make much sense to have a flexible coupling at the bottom ;-)
Make sure that the motor shaft does not extend into the flexible part of the coupling.

description.text: Clip on foot to use with 80/20 aluminum extrusion.

This is an entry to the Chip-E competition. I received inspiration from older robot shows I used to watch and I like the nerdy theme of robots. Enjoy! if you would like to get the arms to move freely you would need bearings : https://www.mcmaster.com/#60355k502/=18hi3sv
The Bearings are for 3/16" Shaft Diameter, and have 1/2" OD.

solid works was the software used for the build.

  1. download all the files
  2. convert the files to .SLDPRT file extension
  3. once I did this an original assembly was created and then a duplicate was created to use as the modified one.
  4. using one component the foundation was created and the rest of the assembly was created

print_settings.Notes:: after printed color the viking press it into the coaster clear coat the viking being careful not to get clear on coaster(you can clear viking before then just apply a good amount of clear on edges once it is placed in coaster) To seal any openings or condensation from a cold item sweating on warm days might leak and get surface wet which will defeat the whole reason you are using a coaster in the first place i plan on using a felt material on bottoms that will protect the surface it sits on as well as cover any light that shines thru(yes it has a coat of clear coat to seal the part but it is clear so light comes thru as you can see in the pic. HAPPY PRINTING!!!

title: Vawt vertical wind turbine urban country home design
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi,this vawt bladed turbine is still a work in progress,and i will be researching more on how to improve my design.
Printing the blades in plastic,then a silicon mould pour from one of the vawt blades,then pouring dascar plastic to make my blades,over time exposure to the UV radiation in sunlight will degrade plastics,finding the right dascar plastics to make my blades,light metal rods to hold the blades,for the pieces that come under stress of movement,for a larger turbine my other downloads urban wind turbine,to be made in pieces if you require a full working power generator, the bottom stand i designed to take double pegs,in time a more portable camping model.
